Comments_List: Basic introductory chemistry concepts, its what youd expect from Gen Chem

I developed time management skills because the problem sets took some time to complete so I had to make sure I left enough time to work on them. I also learned how important actually going to class is, which sounds silly, but I found that I paid more attention when I was actually sitting in class than when I was looking at a screen in my bed.

What you'd expect from a general chemistry course. It starts off quite similar to AP Chemistry [if you've taken it in high school] but it goes more in depth, especially as the semester progresses, so you'll learn some new chemistry too.
A gained an understanding of the basic principles of chemistry.

I gained a better understanding of chemistry in general. Additionally, this course inspired me to actually pursue chemistry as a major. I feel like this course was pretty cool and engaging, and it definitely created a fun learning environment for chemistry.
I felt like this course was a good chemistry introduction. I learned about gas behavior, atomic theory, intermolecular forces, etc.

I learned a lot of the fundamental chemistry concepts, and even though the course was extremely large, there were things done to make it more fun like Dr. G's demos, chemistry section, and discussion sections, as well as textbook help and class lectures. I also liked the setup of having two instructors for chemistry: both Mioy and Prof Holland because I really liked the way Mioy taught.
I learned the basic principles of chemistry from molar concentrations to thermodynamic and molecular orbital theory. A lot of material was covered, so I gained a lot of knowledge...
I learned about chemistry. It clarified any misconceptions I may have developed in high school. It helped to set a strong foundation for my future chemistry courses.
I learned problem-solving techniques and how to approach problems when I don't know where to start.
I developed greater understanding of the concepts of general chemistry.  I learned about the resources available to students for help at Yale.
Understanding of basic chemical processes.
Chemistry basics like redox reactions and perfect gas law
I gained an introductory knowledge of chemistry. I liked how the class was more focused on actually problem solving as well, and would give the applications of what was being taught.

The course covers basic introductory chemistry concepts and then we learned about gas laws, thermo, basic quantum, bonds, and molecular structure.  I feel I got a pretty solid foundation in these topics that will be helpful in later chem courses.
Basic chem stuff: how to balance reactions, trends on the periodic table, redox reactions, polymers, lattice energies, calorimetry. Much was review from high school chemistry.
I learned the basics of a broad range of topics within general chemistry.
Broad, basic general chemistry topics. Lots of problem solving and applications of formulas.
Basic General Chemistry.
I learned about many chemistry principles.

I learned a great deal about chemistry. Though I was already familiar with most of the concepts from high school, we approached them from a slightly different angle and often went more in-depth than I had before.
Very good intro to chemistry. Understood everything I didn't in high school.
Very good understanding of chemistry principles, setting the basis for later chemistry courses. Very good explanation for everything, helping everything to make sense.
Basic chemistry.
I learned the basics of introductory chemistry.
I learned about the basics of chemistry and how to solve chemistry problems.
This course improved my time management skills and my ability to work with others.
I learned chemistry at the college-level.
I definitely had to learn how to operate in a large lecture class.
I gained a better knowledge of chemistry as a whole.

Gen Chem teaches you all of the basic material covered in something like AP Chem at a very accessible level. Things like redox reactions, aqueous chemistry, thermodynamics, etc. are all covered in this course. If you have taken AP Chem, you'll probably want to take Chem 163 instead, but 161 is a very good introduction/foundation for basic, entry-level chemistry.
I learned the fundamental concepts of general chemistry.
Learned a lot about chemistry and its basics.
I gained the ability to think logically, knowledge in essential foundations of chemistry and a a sense of some current chemistry research being conducted.
Basic chem
Learned the foundations of chemistry
I learned how to better understand basic chemistry concepts and apply them to further my knowledge.
I gained some general chemistry knowledge.
I learned basic introductory chemistry concepts
I learned just a lot about chemistry in general: crystal structures, combustion, etc.
How to learn in a big lecture setting.
Learned a few new chemistry concepts as well as exposure to online science problem sets.
Understanding of introductory chemical concepts; math skills (dimensional analysis)
I did learn some basics of chemistry through this course, and it mainly expanded on high school general chemistry.
Relation of Chemistry to real life. Basic chemistry skills.
Basic chemistry knowledge

It's an intro chem course, so you learn basic chemistry. It's not the most challenging class content-wise, but it is frustrating that lectures do not at all facilitate student learning, since for some reason half the class is wasted on unhelpful demonstrations or stupid jokes, and when actual chemistry is reviewed, often only the easiest of concepts from the textbook are emphasized, while tests focus on areas that were not review in lecture.
Basic chemistry concepts that reinforced what I knew and introduced new topics.
How to memorize information.
My skills in chemistry were built during this course.
I learned better problem solving skills, reading comprehension, and the principles of general chemistry.
Learned how to teach myself the material
I learned a lot about basic, intro level chemistry.
I learned basic chemistry and basic computational competencies in chemistry.
I learned concepts of chemistry on both a micro and macro level.
Basic understanding of chemistry topics, ability to problem-solve, and skills in textbook-style reading and learning.
I learned a basic understanding of chemistry, with some in depth teaching of concepts I had not seen before.

I was able to learn the basics of chemistry through the beginning of solids. I got much better at staying on top of my work and making sure I understood the material as we went on because there were many checkpoints whether it be through weekly psets or weekly quizzes.
I developed analytical and practical skills and learned to relate what I studied in real life.

It was essentially AP Chemistry but on steroids. It was very fast-paced chemistry and I mainly learned from my peers and the psets on Sapling. The textbook was moderately decent for learning from but can be confusing. Additionally, having to be confused about the material and having to wait until the lectures and discussion sections for my confusion to be cleared up was a little frustrating. Overall though, I have a really good foundation for future chemistry courses and developed good study habits.
I learned the basics of chemistry.
Stoichiometry, gas laws, thermodynamics, MO theory
I learned the importance of teaching myself the material before showing up to class. If I did not do the reading ahead of time I would have had no idea what was going on during the class.
I feel that I learned how to study more efficiently by taking this course. I also learned the value of discussing material in order to gain a more substantial understanding of it.

I learned the basic introductory level of chemistry from the first semester of this course. No where prepares you for more yale science courses better than the introductory courses at yale, and this is one of the better ones. I learned what it's like to be in a big lecture. This one wasn't too bad.

It was mostly a review of high school chemistry (no harder than AP/IB chem for the first 3/4 of the semester), but at the end of the semester a good amount of new material was introduced which was challenging, but well explained (crystals, polymers, etc. etc.).

I found that this class was almost entirely a review of AP chemistry concepts. This class gave me the opportunity to brush up on some concepts but did not teach me anything new or particularly interesting about these topics.
chemistry
I thought this course was a great introductory course for chemistry. It moves at a comfortable pace and builds a strong foundation for the more complicated, broader science of chemistry.
I developed a stronger foundation for my chemistry and feel more prepared to move to harder topics.
Helped bring back old chem knowledge
We studied a broad view of chemistry, touching on several different topics like gas laws, thermochemistry, solubility, solids, etc...

I learned a great deal about how college classes work and how to handle big lectures such as chem 161.  I also solidified a lot of concepts that were introduced to me during AP chem, and some new material, such as introduction to polymers.
General understanding of chemistry and basic math behind it.

I learned a lot of basic chemistry knowledge, although it was not all directly related to each other it will definitely be useful for futures chemistry courses. I also gained more test taking and question analyzing skills.

How to study ahead of time for midterms and the final exam, how to get my assignments in on time even when they are due early in the mornings, and how to reach out and ask for help when I was stuck or confused about something as big as a concept or as little as a part of a question.
I got the basic tools and skills to be able to continue learning chemistry on a higher level.
The course definitely does a very good job of covering the fundamental knowledge of chemistry and sets a good foundation for moving on to more advanced courses.

I developed knowledge of basic chemistry that will definitely be helpful as I continue along the pre-med track. By the end of the course, I was able to much more easily make connections between chemistry concepts when I was not able to before.

I learned a broad range of concepts in stoichiometry, chemical properties and reactions, general principles such as the ideal gas law and molecular geometry, and how electrons interact with forces within molecules and between molecules. I learned new techniques for problem-solving such as the COAST method and learned a significant amount of infrastructure knowledge for chemistry at both the molecular and atomic level.
The course provides a broad overview of general chemistry knowledge.
I learned basic chemistry concepts that allowed me to understand more about the world around me and how it functions.
I gained a deeper understanding of chemistry concepts.
problem solving
I definitely learned time management because if I worked efficiently and stayed on top of my work, the workload seemed more than manageable for me.
Basic chemistry

Handling an introductory course and understanding a lecture style class.

I developed a stronger foundation of chemistry than AP Chemistry provided, good study strategies, a solid understanding of what to expect in Yale science courses, and learned how to keep up with a large, fast-moving lecture.
Basic chemistry skills, identifying types of problems, and solving techniques.

I gained a lot of knowledge regarding chemistry, including simple topics I learned in high school as well as newer topics that my previous classes had not covered. I gained a lot of intuitive skills on how to apply the chemistry I learn to either problems on a test or real life applications.
I gained a lot of foundational knowledge on chemistry and how to solve and analyze problems in science critically.
I mastered the topics we covered after having already learned them previously in high school.
I learned how to find help from other resources.
I learned a lot of chemistry fundamentals to me it seems like a pretty good intro course.
I gained a better knowledge of basic chemistry, both reviewing concepts I had previously studied and learning new concepts like molecular orbitals or unit cell packing.
Learned everything thanks to my TA. The course itself didnt teach me anything.
Basic chemistry knowledge
Baseline chemistry.
Before taking this course my background in chemistry was very weak. So everything that I now know was learned in this course.
A basic understanding of chemistry

I spent most of the semester telling people this was a trash class. The work was a lot of high school-level memorization in bulk. Within this framework, reading the textbook was far more efficient irntbsnd productive than attending lectures.
The skills I developed by taking this course included time management skills, being able to handle new concepts at a fast pace, and learning from past errors.
I gained a strong background in chemistry for more advanced courses I take.
This class taught me new materials and also went deeper into what I had already learned in high school chemistry.
I strengthened my knowledge of general chemistry and learned how to better study.
I learned the basics of chemistry.
I learned some fundamentals in chemistry that will be helpful in the future.

I learned a lot, I sharpened up my math skills, became really familiar with the elements, and began to really understand the chem part of biochemistry. I lacked a chem background, and I'm glad I was introduced to it in this manner.
Critical thinking and problem solving skills
I learned about a lot of concepts in chemistry and learned about pacing myself and self-study
Basic chemistry skills like stoichiometry and manipulation of various chemical equations; very calculation heavy.
I learned more about chemical processes and more specific general chemistry knowledge and skills that built upon my high school chemistry education.

This course teaches quick and effective problem solving. The material that is taught in lecture is applied to various different problems throughout the semester. We were also taught a specific method of problem solving (COAST) that was used throughout the semester.
I strengthened my knowledge of many of the fundamentals of chemistry.
An intro to chemistry, from the basics, to thermochemistry, to bonding, to molecular diagrams, to crystal structures and polymers.
Builds upon high school chemistry courses.  Through this course, I learned chemical properties, interactions, and how to use equations to solve for missing values.
I gained knowledge of basic chemistry concepts and quantitative skills needed for a good foundation.
I gained some knowledge about chemical equations and problem solving

I learned a lot about concepts like stoichiometry, gas behavior, chemical reactions, atomic properties/trends, quantum numbers, and bonding. I learned how to do dimensional analysis, balance reactions, calculate percent yields, write electron configurations, determine solubility, perform thermodynamics calculations, use Hess' Law, use the idea gas law, analyze intermolecular forces/interactions, calculate freezing/boiling points, analyze packing structures, and analyze polymers. I also learned a little about climate change and its causes and effects. Oh and, of course, I learned the formulas for many polyatomic ions.
I developed a deeper understanding of chemistry and grew more confident in my ability to problem solve and apply my textbook knowledge of chemistry to actual problems.
I learned the fundamentals of chemistry. The first month was reminiscent of high school chemistry then we launched into more complex topics by the second midterm.
I formed a good base for later chemistry and stem courses and learned how to participate in a larger lecture-style class.

I gained a basic understanding of the underlying principles of chemistry. I solidified my dimensional analysis and problem solving skills, as well as learned how to go about a large science lecture course.

I learned the importance of keeping up with the textbook and making sure I understand whole concepts by actively doing practice problems. I also understood the importance of asking for help since nothing was taught during class.
A basic knowledge of gen chem
I learned a lot about chemistry and about managing my time.
I developed skills to foundational chemistry.

I gained a lot of knowledge about chemistry. The course covered everything I learned in high school, but with more detail, so I feel as though I learned a lot more. I also learned some time management skills and studying habits.
my chemistry knowledge increased i guess

I learned general chemistry (what's taught in high school AP Chemistry) which pertained to the topics of stoichiometry, gas laws, periodic table trends, and more. The most important skill I learned from this course was time management. It allowed me to understand what a regular college course load was like. This is a relatively hard class for first-years (who haven't taken AP Chem) but it will teach them how to get used to the average workload.
I learned the intro course material for chemistry.
I learned a lot of basic chemistry that far exceeded what I was taught in my high school honors chemistry course. I also learned about time management in preparation for tests.

The class was an intense introduction to college chemistry. The course covered topics introduced in high school and expanded upon them much more thoroughly. In the beginning, I learned how to be a better student in some aspects in order to keep up.
Class was interesting but it failed to work at a pace that was appropriate for all students.
I learned one semesters worth of basic chemistry
Basic principles of chemistry.
Introductory Chemistry knowledge.
I gained a solid base of chemistry knowledge, and skills relating to balancing equations and using dimensional analysis to find my way through a problem.

My high school knowledge of chemistry was greatly improved upon and refreshed, as I hadnt taken Chemistry since 10th grade. Chem 161 also went much further than what I had learned in high school, and included a lot more calculations that what I had previously done in chem.

I believe through this course a basic understanding of chemistry is a accomplished on the fundamental topics. I think the problem sets were most helpful and I used them as a learning tool often, since it was the only feedback we received aside from the exams. I wish more intermediate feedback had been given, rather than just the midterms.
I found that I learned a lot about chemistry based concepts and even things important to chemistry in everyday life. I also think that I learned the best ways for me to study.
I learned some dimensional analysis, pvt rules, and others. It was a lot of memorization.
I learned about basic chemistry from this course.
I developed newer study skills and learning adaptations that I otherwise would not have developed if I hadn't taken this course.
I learned various problem-solving methods in the field of chemistry, as well as chemistry language.
I developed a strong understanding of basic chemistry. I also learned that when answering questions in a 100+ person lecture hall, one needs to speak up.
I learned about basic, general chemistry topics.
I learned everything I know about chemistry and gained some stud habits.
I developed knowledge about the basics of chemistry, at a higher level than I had learned in high school.

Strengths: Professor Holland was a cool teacher, and the material really isnt that complicated. 

Weaknesses: the class feels like it takes a lot of time, since you have class three times a week and you also have mandatory section once a week. Also, theres assignments (albeit very short) for each class meeting, other than the weekly psets, which are easy to forget about.

The class covered a lot of material which was good. Sometimes, though, it felt as though the level of the practice problems and the problems we did in class were much easier than the problems on the test. I think it would have been better if there had been problems that were similar to test questions in the problem sets.

I loved the interactive aspects of the course, so the parts of class when Dr. G would come up and do an experiment or when Professor Holland brought out balloons to show us the molecular geometry of different molecules. Those really helped build my knowledge about the topics we were talking about, and it was fun! However, there were some times when I felt like I wasn't really learning much because Professor Holland was going kind of fast and not actually explaining the concept, just showing how it related to some real-life example. I really liked the way Mioy taught because he explained every concept in detail, which was very helpful.

Strengths: 
 - Sapling practice problems/problem sets: It helped me learn the material, and some of the problems were similar to the test.
- Discussion section: Having us work together in small groups to solve problems was very helpful. It was engaging, and the problems were usually challenging, but it was a good low stakes environment to practice. The quizzes could be hard, but they aren't worth much, and you get points for participating basically. The only issue I had was that section was too short, and it ALWAYS ran over the assigned time. Also, the students had way too many questions for 1 TF to handle by herself, poor Coraline.

Weaknesses: 
- The cost: I had the pleasure (heavy sarcasm) of taking this course right as they decided to change the textbook edition, so I couldn't get a used edition from upperclassmen. I had to buy a brand new book and it was really expensive. Also, Sapling is a good resource, but it's $40 a semester! It's ridiculous to pay that much money just for the ability to turn in your homework. 
- Homework discussions: Useless. Since there are 300ish people in this class, you can't have any sort of meaningful discussion. And having to make a post 3 times a week just felt excessive to me. 
- Lectures: Lecture was 3 times a week, which is a lot! Generally I didn't feel a lot of motivation to go. Usually I did not receive very much new insight. Reducing lecture to 2 times a week or just getting rid of it altogether would've been more helpful. I personally feel like the class would've been more engaging and more conducive to learning it was less lecture-style and more discussion section-style.

A strength of this course is its repetition of content in different ways. The readings, problems, sections and then psets ensured that I learnt the materials. I also found it useful to go through practice problems during lecture, because this is how we are tested. Most of the demonstrations are engaging, but I would suggest that it is not necessary to have a demonstration if it does not enhance our understanding. I also think that the class should start at 10:30 as indicated on CourseSearch. It would enable us to get through everything and also leave at 11:20 if we have a class directly after chemistry.

Strengths: I think the set up of the course is very good for learning. I really benefited from the practice problems on Sapling as well as the course instruction by the professor. I think the grading system was fair as well. Additionally, Holland had some pretty fun incentives and prizes throughout the semester that kept the class engaging and fun. 

Weaknesses: There was supposed to be this great focus on collaboration and working together, but I feel like this idea was actually lost throughout the course. Some of the other TFs that I would go to their section instead, they made everyone work alone and did not encourage collaboration. Additionally, I feel like topics were rushed at the end of the semester.
It would be helpful to have more practice problems provided before exams in addition to practice tests.
The amount of workload could be reduced

I thought that sometimes the course content was not as clear as it should be, like when learning VSEPR there should have been 3D modeling because I had a hard time visualizing 3D concepts. Sometimes the tests were not graded fairly, like when I lost 12 points off a test question for misbalancing 1 equation.

As far as introductory lectures go, I thought it was taught very well. It was engaging and helpful, and there was a good mixture of self accountability and communal support. I liked having multiple chances on the sapling homeworks. I felt like that motivated me to continue trying to solve the problems without looking at the hints or at online resources for help. One weakness was that the excel sheet for homework was incorrect many times, so sometimes I thought there was no homework when there was...

The course is very demanding. The structure has time sensitive assignments that keep you engaged with chemistry all the time. Sometimes the lectures stray from the topics in the book, which is okay because I understand a professor wants to keep things interesting. However, too many tangents can disengage the students.

The in-class demonstrations were very helpful and engaging. Also, I thought the problem sets and practice problems accurately reflected the material being covered and helped me understand the concepts. One thing that I would improve on was the consistency of information. There were a few times where we got emails clarifying certain topics that were not explained correctly during the lecture.

The strengths: Dr. Huynh is one of the best teachers I have had so far at Yale.  He is extremely clear and really wants to help his students.  The problem sets on Sapling were very worthwhile in better understanding the material.  The peer tutors are also very good.

The weaknesses:  The misconception that Chemistry should be taught as a discussion or a seminar is an unfortunate aspect of this course.  The time that Prof. Holland spent giving us his teaching philosophy was a good indication of how useless lecture was going to be.  The focus on "fun" science and real world application is not at all useful to grasping the material. I wish that professor Holland had focused more on the content of the book.  Although student are supposed to be familiar with the material from doing the readings, if the material is not reinforced and explained in class, there is no purpose in attending class.

weakness: practice exams were much easier than actual exam. also, section worksheets, they didn't give us the answers to the problems so we couldn't know if what we were doing was right or not, and we were to take a quiz on the material in the last five min of section. just be mindful of that.
Teaching is very impersonal and lecture material, while engaging, was not always helpful for exams.
If you didn't understand something, I thought it was hard to get help. However, I did like the fast pace of the class and Professor Holland made lectures a little less dull.

I think the course covered a lot of material. The sections and pre-lecture questions were helpful.

I felt like the discussions before lectures weren't completely necessary, especially with other pre-lecture material. I also felt like the learning was heavily dependent on reading. Also, the Sapling questions were fine, but weren't always similar to exam questions.

Strength: You cover a lot of material and learn a lot over the semester.
Weakness:  Although class is helpful, the most important part of this class is the textbook.  It could be more engaging.
I think that this course could be improved by having more of an emphasis on the concepts. I think that it was just assumed that many people understood a topic before they were even taught them.

I feel that class time could be used a lot more efficiently, although it might be at the cost of cutting back on demos. 

My main complaint is how the discussion sections are run. Sometimes, no one in our group would know how to do a certain problem and although our TA could guide us, she couldn't out-right show up step by step how to do the problem. This meant that sometimes I would leave the session being unsure about whether I really understood how to do a problem. However, after the session, she was more than happy to go over any questions we had.

The biggest strength of this course was the amount of practice problems available to students. There were numerous practice exams to try before each hour-long exam, and countless problems from the book / Sapling problem sets / Sapling practice problems to learn from. I knew (more or less) what kinds of information Professor Holland wanted us to know because of all the various types of practice available. Another strength of this course is the sheer number and availability of office hours. There are literally so many times and places you can meet with a TF / instructor / peer tutor to help you. 

One weakness of this course was that lectures were not always useful. Sometimes we focused on things in lecture that were not going to be on the exam - I didn't really see the point of this. Demos in class were fun but not always instructive.

MIOY HUNYH WAS THE STRENGTH OF THIS COURSE!!! Officially, he was the preceptor of the class, but I learned so much from him. He was very friendly with students and always was more than willing to answer questions. Make friends with Mioy and ask him questions throughout the term. He's incredible.
Lots of resources to ensure success (practice problems, discussion sections, problem sets, extra help, etc.). Could be improved by discussing exam-like questions and topics during lecture.
Its really just hard because its so crowded, but the weekly sections make a huge difference in students understanding.
Lectures could be made to be more useful. Sometimes, I felt like I didn't have to be there and I could just get the information elsewhere.
The lectures were not very helpful and I think we should learn more in lecture since reading from the textbook and trying to teach ourselves the material is challenging.

I am personally not a fan of the flipped classroom. The lectures sometimes provided information relevant to students, but most of the time I thought they lacked important information.

A lot of the information presented in lectures, however, was very interesting, which helped with engagement.

I think that Prof. Holland's lectures were quite engaging and generally clearly conveyed topics covered in the textbook. (I also appreciated that they were available on Canvas.) The weekly quizzes in discussion section were a useful way to have feedback on many different topics. Sometimes, though, I felt that too much time was spent on simpler issues and less time on more confusing ones; perhaps being able to focus some lectures based on feedback regarding what topics were most confusing in the reading would be helpful, though it might be hard to pull off. Also, I disliked the Reflection questions that weren't particularly relevant to reading or class and required internet research into random topics  I felt that they didn't add to my understanding and were a bit of a waste of time.
Not a very engaging course, but there were A LOT of resources to help. The live experiments every class were very fun and helped solidify our understanding of what was being taught in lecture.

The syllabus moves very fast, and sometimes a lot of studying has to be done at home to learn things and keep up with what's going on. Also the discussion section was not very helpful because the TFs were not allowed to give us the answers to the worksheets which I I did not find useful.

The strengths were honestly the extra resources/review sessions that Dr. Huynh provided to help the students understand the material beyond the required readings and the lectures. I also thought the Sapling p-set were good practice, but they didn't reflect how the actual exam questions tested the material at all, so I'd count that as a weakness.  I found the reflection questions more confusing than helpful in interacting with the readings. I wish clicker questions in class more reflected what would appear on the exams.

The strengths of this course are streaming it live. I also found that the course had many opportunities for practice problems that reflected the material on the exam.

In the future, I think that Prof. Holland's lectures should more accurately reflect the relevant material. The textbook reading would often not fully be covered during lecture, and so it was difficult to distinguish relevant from inconsequential information. Too much of the class time was taken up by going over reflections or by applications to the real world that while interesting did not further my understanding of the material.
Even though the course was very fast-paced, I was able to gain a solid foundation in various chemistry topics.
This course did a satisfactory job teaching concepts and staying away from rote learning. The class could be improved if the practice tests were more representative of the real tests.
More focus could be put on harder concepts.

Well lecture was kinda a huge waste of time, I thought. I think a more robust use of the chalkboards, and less of the slideshow presentations, would be wildly helpful. Additionally, explaining concepts in class, like before giving examples, would be awesome.
The readings are much more helpful than lectures.

I really liked the Sapling system, which is used for pre-lecture practice quizzes (which I found useful because it actually encouraged me to do the pre-lecture readings) and psets. Sapling was great for psets because it gave you 4 tries on every question, ensuring that you didn't lose points for making a dumb arithmetical error, and also helping you to gain greater understand by fixing your mistakes. Lecture wasn't the most useful thing, but I always went because Holland is a pretty good professor who does a good job of covering the material and explaining it in different ways that might make more sense than the way it's explained in the textbook. Although lectures are recorded and livestreamed, I would highly recommend going to lecture because you'll be way more focused on the material than if you sit in your suite and watch it.
The course can be improved if the professor explains stacking pattern with more visuals.
In the end, we could have talked more about the end material and how to understand the concepts. Also, we could do more exam type questions during class to verify concepts.
No significant strengths, no significant weaknesses. In the middle
Weakness: 3 midterms, too many assignments that count too little towards final grade

The course was very flexible to students' needs. Students could choose the amount of help they received and had plenty of additional resources to seek out. The reflections allowed for more critical thinking and engagement with the course content. The course did not have many weakness, other than that certain topics may have been explained a bit more clearly.
Holland is a weakness bc he doesn't do anything during class.  The TAs are decent tho and the exams fair
I would like more organized lectures, with a clear outline of what we're going to learn about in the beginning of the lecture. Also posted note summaries would be super helpful.

Sometimes the information presented in the lecture wasn't relevant to what we should know/be tested on, and often times the hard concepts were skimmed over. More practice problems throughout the lecture would greatly improve the class

I think that the lectures could be more engaging. I found them not very useful for the class in general. I also feel as if discussion sections vary greatly in their effectiveness depending on your TA. I think the reflections were not very helpful but I think the sapling psets were a good way to test your knowledge.
The class could be improved by doing less experiments in lectures.
I think more topics should be covered in lecture instead of spending time on multiple examples for each topic and not getting through a summary of the entire reading during class.

I think a different textbook should be used for the course. The topics didn't flow very well in the textbook and the ordering of the chapters seemed off. I actually like the concept of reading on the lesson before the lesson is taught because it made me more prepared for the lecture but I didn't like how if there was not enough time in the lecture, Professor Holland would say, "Oh, I don't have to go over this because it's already in your textbook." I don't think the textbook does a good job explaining the topics; it overcomplicated everything.
I found the discrepancy between the practice exams and the real exams to be quite great.
The lectures need to focus more on material and less on demonstrations and clicker questions.

A lot of students started the course with a deeper understanding of the concepts that would be covered, so initially discussion section wasn't very helpful since a lot of our peers already knew the material and would breeze through the discussion questions. Sections started getting more helpful once our TF realized some of us were not understanding the concepts.

Also, the material covered in lecture seems easier to understand than what's in the readings and personally, the exams tend to be more difficult than what was covered.

The course is interesting and relatively easy to understand, however, the course lacks an engaging element that encourages people to come to lecture. While having the lecture recorded and posted online was helpful, it discouraged many people from being present in class.

Lectures are recorded, slides are uploaded to canvas. Helpful for learning.
Practice exams uploaded, TFs very engaged.
Readings and Lab Lectures often do not overlap too much. Discussion sections teach way more than Lecture. Lectures sometimes not helpful.

Strengths - the teaching staff were very engaging with the students
Weakness - section wasn't very productive

I think a big strength of the course is that it is designed for students to succeed. I'm not a freshman, but I know it is a course very popular with that class, and it's clear why. Teachers are always available, there are a plethora of peer tutoring opportunities, and classes are recorded for later access. In general, the class is well structured for success. 
I think one of the larger weaknesses in the class is the way assignments are structured. It's not the worst, but having several assignments a night that each have to be turned in on different websites at different times of the day is complicated (and could certainly be streamlined).

The lecture component is horrible. It's no wonder students stop going by two weeks in. Lectures often review the simplest concepts, while assessments do not. It is super frustrating to feel like your time is being wasted in a lecture, when it could be super helpful to review confusing concepts. I think a good remedy would be to switch to two 1 hr 30minute lectures instead of the three 55 minute lectures. There is also an insane disparity in the quality of TAs (which I guess is true of most courses, but especially true of gen chem). One of the TA's literally helps teach the class, while others barely seem to have a grasp on course content. This makes it frustrating when some TA's send out insanely detailed study guides while others do literally nothing to prepare students for their exams.
The discussion sections can be really helpful. But the class can be fast-paced too.
Too much content crammed into a semester.
The strength of the class is the number of resources provided by professor Holland. Lecture also proofed to be very useful in helping understand the material of the class.

The biggest weakness is the difference of quality in the Teaching Fellows. Dr. Mioy was by far the best TF because he provided his students with study guides, powerpoint, and tons of office hours. On top of that, he was helping to write the exams! This gave his students a HUGE advantage and the rest of us who weren't in his section a disadvantage. Because of this, I believe that grades should be curved based on the discussion sections.
Holland is a great guy and I genuinely like him as a person - but I felt like the majority of the learning had to be done on your own and therefore I didn't feel inclined to attend lecture.
The lectures were practically useless.  They elaborated and explained the course material no better than the textbook.  Sections and text book readings were the only useful sources of information.

The recorded videos made a world of difference. the instructor did a great job at teaching the concepts and was complemented well by the TF. I felt I learned the material efficiently and with no use of the textbook with is ideal. 

A major weakness was the constant reflections and practice problems due before each test. they were tedious and were no test of my competency in the course material. They greatly lowered my final mark since I constantly forgot about them. I would much rather 2 p-sets be assigned every week in their place or a longer p-set. I feel that my mark will not reflect my performance on the midterms and final, but is instead determined too much by my participation. in the end I know the material, and can show my competency. this was a product of the time and work put in, yet the reflections were irrelevant and determined far too much of my final grade.

Strengths: 
The professor is very engaging and enthusiastic about the subject.  The demonstrations in each lecture kept me curious and helped me to better understand the concepts that we were learning.  The discussion sections were helpful as well.  

Improvements: 
The tests were often very rushed.  I knew the general concepts and processes, however, I did not have adequate time to show my understanding.

This course is (in theory) formatted and spaced out well, but the reality for most students is that we struggled to keep up with the nightly textbook readings, and then ended up trying to cram hundreds of pages of information the week before the  3 exams. The problem sets and nightly problems were helpful, but they were so easy that you usually didn't even need to do the reading to solve them (likewise with the non-specific nature of the canvas discussions). The problems sets, and especially the format of the lectures was not representative of the difficulty of exam problems. One strength of the class is that you can drop the lowest exam score (which I think is really important for students, and especially first-years struggling to understand the work required of them for this class).  
The general attitude surrounding this class is that you take it because you have to, not because you want to. I think that Professor Holland tried his best to bring a sense of excitement towards the subject material, but he had his work cut out for him.
The strength of this class was the pacing, as it wasn't too fast or too slow, however, the amount of midterms could have been reduced.

They keep you on top of the material and with the three midterms you are able to study as the course is going rather than cramming at the end. Additionally being able to drop one is definitely a plus. The course could be improved through an elimination of the sort of flipped classroom agenda. A lot of the information is difficult to understand and if it were actually taught during class rather than just using abstract examples to try and relate the concepts to the students, everyone would benefit.

I did not have access to chemtour videos and my friends who used it said it was very helpful. Some chapters in the textbook were more dense than others making it unbalanced.
the course was very fun and engaging.

Get rid of reflections and practice problems for saplings. They were tedious rather than helpful. I searched up other worksheets and other problems from the books to do. Reflections added no insight into my learning.
I liked the use of turnining point clickers as well as the discussion section meetings.
The class was well paced.

There was so much material to be taught throughout this semester and I thought that the teaching was lacking. There was a lot of time spent in class going over things that had little to no relevance to the material being learned.
The one weakness of the course was its size but this was remedied by the discussion sections which aided learning.

Strengths: good professor, give you the basic chemistry, pretty enjoyable lectures, good demonstrations, good TA help.

Weaknesses: big lecture, less personal, grading a little unclear, but it is straight forward

The strengths of the course were the instructors and the vast resources available to students taking this class. Everything imaginable was provided to help students succeed in this class: peer tutors, recordings of each lecture, and a PhD instructor who offered tutoring sessions every week 4 hours a week, just to name a few. I'd also say that the course was fair; if you put in the work, you got the grade you deserved. No frills. Weaknesses, sadly, were the lectures. Although Prof. Holland is a wonderful cheerleader for chemistry and knows how to inspire his students or make them laugh, he teaches in a somewhat hand-wavy, over-assuming way and rarely explained fundamental concepts thoroughly. This is problematic because although this was a quantitive reasoning class, the most difficult problems on exams required excellent conceptual footing and most students came into the students with little foundational knowledge. When Dr. Huynh lectured, it was like learning from a classmate who "got it;" he clearly understood the struggles of beginning chemistry students and explained concepts as if students had never, ever seen them before. He also "got into the weeds" and solved problems on the chalkboard, not only hard questions but easy ones as well. This is fantastic! I think that for lectures about topics such as moles or the history of chemistry, Prof. Holland cannot be beat, but Dr. Huynh would have been much, much appreciated on days when the most confusing topics were being introduced such as MO theory and crystal packing.

The strength of this course was the assistant professor, Mioy Huynh. Mioy deftly explained concepts that were not fully explored in class. He also created many practice exams, extra problems, and concise and clear notes. He was cheerful, helpful, and kind. Without Mioy, I would have had a much harder time with this class. The class could be improved by having notes like Mioys available to the entire class. In addition, it would be helpful if more class time could be spent discussing and explaining new topics in more detail instead of watching demos. I found the sapling problems sets useful, and perhaps doing more practice like those problems instead of written reflections would be helpful.

strengths: I learned chemistry
weaknesses: I could have learned more chemistry

I thought the pace of the class and problem sets were fantastic. I also liked the practice problems since they kept me on pace with the class. I thought the lectures could have done a better job covering the material. I also thought the section quizzes were unnecessary stress-inducers.

The course is very fast-paced and very organized so that a chapter is read each week. The weakness is that the lectures did not provide any new content from the book and sometimes does not help in clearing up unclear ideas.
Lectures could be a little more engaging, problem set dates could be put on canvas. The practice problems helped teach info.

I thought that section was very beneficial but lecture was not that beneficial.  I think that lecture time could be more effective in going over the material and practice problems rather than reviewing student responses.  Sapling was helpful but the problems were much easier than the exams.

Strengths: efficient sections

Weakness: sometimes gaps between reading and lectures
The main strength was that there were many supplementary resources and the main weakness was that it was a lecture course and so individualized help was not really available.

Strengths are the entertaining demonstrations during the lectures that solidified my understanding of a concept with a memorable experiment, and the high level of engagement with the TAs. Weakness is that sometimes the lectures did not fully cover a lesson/chapter in the book deep enough, so there was quite a bit of self-studying involved.

Strengths were that there were many different ways to seek help and get different perspectives on the course material. Weaknesses were that going to lecture sometimes was not really helpful if you just read the chapters in the book.
The material is presented in many ways which is helpful with gaining familiarity with it.

The main strength of this course was its teaching. Professor Holland did a great job covering all the important chemistry concepts that we should know and on which we would be tested. The one weakness that I can think of is that some topics were covered a bit quickly, so I needed to use supplementary material to better understand the concept.

Strengths: the textbook was particularly helpful and the TF discussion sections were helpful. 
Weakness: the lectures were difficult to understand if the readings were confusing; I wish the lectures went over practice word problems more often.
Studying for tests in the class were very difficult. many of the practice tests, while helpful, were not representative of the actual test themselves.
I don't think lecture was as useful as doing actual practice problems and the problem sets by yourself.
Lecture was not very helpful due to class size, but the book was very good. Office hours were also helpful.
This course has many strengths including the structure of the course that reinforces information with a lot of practice. I cannot think of weaknesses except how far the class is.
weakness: pace was too fast
I thought the lectures could include more relevant . information to the topics. I felt that I learned more about exam topics in the discussion sections than lectures.
I didn't think lecture was the a good use of time - I think two longer lectures rather than three shorter ones would be more beneficial.
Strengths were the TFs and the weaknesses was the lack of preparation for exams

The lecture is not helpful at all. If the lecture was more focused on practice problem, learning the concepts of this class would be easier. Also, practice exams were not helpful because Professor Holland routinely made them much easier than the actual exam. It would be helpful to know how deep of an understanding of the concepts is expected of us beforehand. Tests should be based on your mastery of the concepts, not how well you can handle Professor Hollands surprises.

Strengths -- my TA was amazing, caring, and incredibly helpful. Class was somewhat interesting and Professor Holland was entertaining and interested in teaching and was very open to answering questions. Lots of office hours and extra help was available.
Weaknesses -- lectures aren't extremely useful except for announcements like when the exams are and when the problem sets are due. There is no notification for when Sapling problem sets are due on Canvas (even though there are notifications for the daily Sapling practice problems that don't count for anything), so it's really easy to miss problem sets that are worth a lot of points.
The discussion sections aren't very helpful. I think they should be more focused on highlighting the most difficult skills/concepts from each chapter that will be tested.
The backwards learning style was not effective. Lectures were very unhelpful
More practice problems in class would be helpful. 40 minutes seemed inadequate for many of the lessons.

Strengths: Prof. Holland is a great lecturer, demos break up lecture nicely and are occasionally helpful (but not directly translatable) for recalling info on exams. Very interesting material presented in a comprehensible way, Prof. Holland and the TAs were great about getting exams back quickly.
Weaknesses: Class rarely started on time so it went over to fit all of the necessary material, which is understandable but with student having to leave to run to classes on Old Campus, etc. (also understandable), engagement/focus by the last few slides was usually very low. Not all discussion sections are created equal. After some lectures I felt that time might've been better spent rereading the textbook section.

Comprehensive on the basics. Some of the TFs were amazing however  if TF was not as willing to delve into the material in section it can be easy to become confused in class or when doing homework problem.
The weaknesses were that you had to learn most of the material.

The strengths of this class is the way the material is taught. I liked the lecture style and the fact that we were always following a set schedule both with the readings as well as the practice problems due every week. Another strength was the time it takes to get exams back- the TA's were able to give us back every exam within 2 days of taking it! One of the main weaknesses of this course was the way the exams were scheduled. We always were given a week after the material for an exam was finished to study and complete practice exams before the scheduled exam date. Although we were given this extra time, we were still moving forward learning material for the next exam. This meant that by the time we were taking an exam, some of the material we were tested on was learned even before we took the previous exam. This set up, although most likely the only one that works for a class of this size, was always made it difficult to manage the spread of material for one exam.

I really like the interactive elements of the course with the demos and Sapling problems as they helped me learn the course material very well. This course could be improved in terms of the discussion sections, which I found to be not as helpful in terms of learning the material. The discussion sections could be changed in their structure so that there is more of an interactive element.
The lectures weren't very helpful. The online resources provided by the book were nice, though. I also liked the practice exams that were provided.
I liked how there were many resources to get help. I think this class could've of done more to allow students to have a clearer idea of how they were doing in the course.

The main weakness is that lectures are useless  they are modeled to help refine and do practice problems for reading, but they end up being not very helpful and you can get the same amount of insight out of the class if you just read the textbook closely. In terms of strengths, I think the actual material is useful and interesting  it is cool how everything builds on each other to attack some complex topics later on in the semester.

The class time was not spent on material that was challenging. Instead of going over problems that would be similar to those on tests, we spent a lot of time going over simple examples that rarely helped.

The course provides plenty of ways to learn, from lecture to the Sapling program, and the multiple choice questions in class with clickers were also helpful. The discussion section was also very helpful.
The course could better which topics to focus on. I thought lecture focused on irrelevant things and not really what comes on the exam.

Demos, Sapling, and reflection questions were helpful.
Discussions sessions were a waste of time, and TF Reagan can't teach.
The demonstrations during full class meetings are very interesting and engaging.
The lecture doesnt cover enough information on one subject before moving onto the next.
I found that some discussion sections were more helpful than others for me. So it would be great if we could shop different discussion sections.

It would be more helpful doing more test-like questions during class in order to prepare us for the exam. A weakness is that the discussion sections varied in how much we learned based on what TF we got, as some were better than others so it didn't really help teach me the topics.
Strength was lots of resources and engagement, weakness was lecture didnt cover much of what was tested in detail (so reading the textbook is important).
Area for improvement : focus more time on underlying theory

The strengths of this course include the course content being interesting and the teaching fellows being very available to answer questions and help students. Some of the weaknesses include the p-sets not covering material touched on in class and the lack of example covered in class.
It is very impersonal due to a large class size.

I think the strength of this course was that it was mostly appropriately paced and the sapling problem sets were really useful in learning/reviewing the material. Actually, the structure of the homework was really integral in my understanding of the material. I thought that one of the weaknesses was that the actual lecture itself didnt go into depth about the material covered.
The course was very informative. I learned a great deal, especially from the discussion sections.

Regrades maybe could be better? I think it has a lot of strengths: there are some great TA's, plenty of resources (online lecture, book, TFs) and comprehensive PSETS. As a lecture course its not bad, it does go a bit fast for people who did not take AP Chem in HS, but I think thats more of a Yale issue and not specifc to the course itself.

Strengths: lots of opportunities to get help, fun demos, helpful teaching 

Weaknesses: practice tests were often not representative of tests

Because of the large number of people in the lecture it was hard to develop personal relationships with the professor but the discussion sections were very useful and the instruction was clear, lectures were also generally engaging.

This course is weak in introducing concepts to students with a weak background in chemistry and does not focus enough on applications of equations and how to solve problems that might be encountered on exams.

I thought that the discussion section format of going through problems on a worksheet was at times helpful but often somewhat ineffective at getting at key ideas with enough time to actually discuss them with peers/the TA as opposed to completing problems simply for completion's sake.

This course does a really good job of efficiently teaching a lot of material and maintaining student interest throughout the semester. However, the material after the third exam felt a bit rushed and like an afterthought. This could be improved by possibly starting those topics earlier or having review sessions specifically for those chapters.

Strengths: great insights into how chemistry works, fun demos, fair grading
Weaknesses: very far up science hill

Lectures are too frequent and the Sterling Chemistry Lab building is very far from campus.  For this reason, I often taught myself material through the textbook and online tutorials.  TAs are very helpful and responsive to emails.
The lectures could have addressed the concepts better. For example, we were often given real-life examples when it would have been more helpful to go a little more in depth on certain concepts.
The discussion sections were helpful, but the weekly quizzes did not leave much room for error.

I appreciated that lecture involved demonstrations by Doctor G and Professor Holland, it made class enjoyable. I think it would be beneficial to have practice test problems, which are presented as clicker questions, to be more challenging with a walk-through or explanation after the correct answer is presented.
The lecture component of the course was barely teaching us anything. It felt like we did all of the learning out of the textbook, which was confusing. Problem solving in class is not that helpful.
The course has many weaknesses in it's lecture which seems to be able to be skipped entirely because no actual material is taught. Everything is selflearned in this course.

The practice problems and problem sets on Sapling helped a lot to solidify the concepts we learned in the textbook and in lectures. The mandatory discussions at first weren't helping me at all, but by the end of the semester they were doing a lot for me. It's great that the lectures and slides are all posted online and that you can watch them live. The main weaknesses of the course are its massive size (huge lectures) and the fact that you can fall behind easily and no one will be there to lift you back up unless you actively seek someone out. The extra problem-solving sessions were wonderful! The course could be improved by making extra practice worksheets or extra Sapling practice problems available.

The main strength is that it is a course that through its evaluations forces students to study. The tests are a bit limited in terms of time and it is a bit of a rush but also encourages you to work faster and more efficiently. The main weakness is that this course doesn't mandate or incentivize participation. Therefore, I feel there should be a greater incentive to attend lecture.

Strengths: it moved quickly which helped me stay engaged, the lectures were well done by Patrick Holland, there was lots of practice and extra help available.
Weaknesses: The first two tests were far more difficult than practice materials, chemistry is inherently boring, there is no flexibility in deadlines becuase the class is so large and standardized

The problem sets are often too simple or dont actually aid in understanding the concepts. It would be helpful if there were a more clear outline of topics since the book is quite dense and contains a lot of extraneous information.

Strength: the practice exams 
Weakness: I still feel like I have a very little understanding of chemistry.

This course is a great intro to chemistry for someone with no prior knowledge, though it can be slow at times. That said, one complaint I have is that the course seems to focus too much on memorization, rather than teaching students to understand why.

The lecture nature of the course makes it difficult to get individualized assistance, even with the inclusion of TA's and discussion sections. The content can be more complicated than how it is explained in the lecture, so the discussion section does help a little bit with getting thorough explanations, but only if you have a good TA. The lecture is too short to gain anything more than a surface understanding of the material, and it's very difficult to teach yourself via the book. The problem sets and practice problems are useful though, and help you understand what kinds of problems will be on the exam and test how well you know the information. More individualized attention would improve this course, and having TA's that are more proactive and responsive to students' questions.

Strengths- lots of resources for help
Weaknesses- students had to learn using the textbook by themselves
I think this course could definitely be taught better. I felt as though the lectures did not help me at all and the tests were extremely difficult.
Grade distribution and an explanation on how that works. Lectures in class about the material instead of going through a couple problems..

Strengths: problem sets and the book
Weaknesses: the lecture was not my favorite
textbook learning sucks have the professor actually teach

The strengths of this course are the amount of resources that the professors gives you to understand the concepts. The weakness is the professor's lack of emphasis on how self-guided this course will be. I would say that 60-70% of this course is self-taught through reading the textbook. Lectures and discussion sections are just there to go over the concepts that you maybe didn't quite understand.
This course is very large, but well organized.

This course has a good professor. The Sapling practice questions were helpful and objective. The grading policy for this course is very nice. The weekly discussion section was very helpful to my understanding. Perhaps one fo the biggest strengths of this course was that it was live-streamed, which kept me motivated to actually watch lecture and take my own notes, especially as it got colder and I no longer wanted to walk up science hill every morning. The course could be improved by going over material more thoroughly at the end of the semester. I felt as though the last two chapters were not discussed enough to properly help me prepare for the final (in fact, it felt as though they really weren't discussed at all).

Professor Holland often rushed lecture, and so I often left class unclear on many things. Section also felt rushed. More than anything, I felt the class was trying to fit too much into one semester. However, I also did not exert enough effort to really immerse myself in the class. As for strengths, the teaching fellows and additional exercises were often very helpful.

Strengths: Professor was entertaining and very good at explaining things, demonstrations were fun

weaknesses: Lectures often felt like a waste of time because they do not teach very much and go very slow.

I think that the strengths are definitely the activities that we did for each class especially the practice problems. They kept me engaged with the material. A weakness, however, is the readings. I didn't find the textbook particularly helpful in learning the material. I felt that a lot of times it just made things more confusing. The lectures and problem sets were much more helpful.
Lecture format discourages engagement, most of the knowledge came from self-studying the textbook.
I would say that a weakness of this course is that so much information is pushed into a semester that you do not really get to study the material in-depth.

Strengths: Comprehensive. We learn a lot of material and there are a lot of opportunities to practice and strengthen understanding, Also, a lot of resources to prepare for exams.

Weaknesses: The pre-class questions were sometimes not relevant. I also did not find the reflections helpful. Sometimes, the class went at an unnecessarily fast pace, and it was difficult to thoroughly understand the material when it was reviewed so quickly during lecture.

This course was good at introducing and reinforcing material in multiple ways. The Sapling software is an AMAZING teaching tool. I do wish that the discussion sections had covered material less than a week after it was introduced, though.

I really enjoyed and appreciated all the demonstrations! They were my favorite part of the class and helped me understand how all the dry formulas we used in this course actually apply to real substances, and some of them were key to my comprehension of particular topics.

One strength of the course was having chem discussion section once a week, as it gave me a chance to review the material in a smaller group, allowing me to ask my peers and my TF more questions.
One weakness is that this class is really only taught by the textbook. Going to lecture is not necessary to learn the information, and honestly sometimes stressed me out because Prof Holland often rushed through the lecture notes and I ended up feeling badly when people would start to leave early (to be fair, he often went over time) when he was trying to include the fun little demo that he promises at the beginning of each full class meeting/lecture. 
I was also frustrated by the fact that we kept moving on with material so that by the time one of the three Midterms came, the content that was on the test would be stuff we learned at least a month ago.

I think the lecture time could be used in a better way. Somehow, we seemed to always run out of time and as a result, certain topics were covered in passing, rather than explained. I appreciated the plethora of office hours and locations for this course and many of the TAs were very helpful. I think that we never er

This course was very difficult, especially as someone who has not taken that much chemistry in high school. I think that certain things were helpful though, such as the practice questions, and sometimes the reflections. I did not find the discussion sections to be as helpful as they could have been. I often wished that there was time for students to be given help with actual concepts. Lastly, I feel as though many of the practice tests given did not reflect the difficulty of the actual exams.
Strengths: information and ways to make it interesting

I would consider my TA Mioy to be a strength in this course because of all the support he offered all his students during review sessions. However, for a class with so much content, there was minimal engagement. The weekly sessions were not very helpful since all fo the Was conduct them differently, thus I think some student were more engaged in the class if their TA was better with engaging students during the weekly discussions. I had both experiences: one where the TA allowed the students to work independently and another who forced students to collaborate in groups by making each group write their answers on the board with a justification. The latter was infinitely more beneficial for learning. It also made asking questions and making mistakes less intimidating and improved my overall retention of the material.

This course was fun to take, but the concepts were not explained as thoroughly during class time as I would have liked. There were so many different resources that I found it hard to concentrate on one that would help me the most.

The strengths are using the clickers to get students involved in the class and the discussion sections that help students understand the material.  The weakness might be the disconnect between students and resources available for students to take advantage of.

The strengths of this course are the problem sets and practice problems through Sapling.  The weaknesses are the lectures as though it is admirable that they incorporate real-life applications for techniques taught, they sometimes contain too much irrelevant information making it difficult to follow the progression of the actual lesson.

This course effectively provides a strong foundation of basic chemistry. I found the Sapling questions and problem sets extremely helpful  I often took notes on the explanations that Sapling provided when I answered incorrectly. I also like that we were given four chances to answer correctly on the problem sets. I was very grateful for the practice tests that Professor Holland posted before every exam  they were excellent study tools. I also enjoyed the demonstrations during lectures. 

This course relies heavily on individual learning  I had to do the reading before the lecture if I wanted to understand anything in the lecture. This was very difficult for me, and I didn't learn as much as I would have liked during the lectures, based on how much class time I spent in the lecture hall. The most useful part of the lectures, for me, were the practice test questions during which I could brainstorm procedures and solutions with my classmates, but, unfortunately, there were not as many practice questions as I would have liked. I wanted more! Furthermore, I did not find the pre-class reflections particularly useful.

I think the lectures were pretty engaging and highlighted the important and most difficult topics from the reading. It was also very helpful that all of the lectures were live-streamed and recorded. Discussion sections were a really good way to get extra practice and further explanation on all of the material. A weakness  of this course is the number of exams, because I felt we had too many midterms. I fell like having less midterms would give us more opportunity to really focus on the information presented class rather than always having to scramble to study for the next exam, so it was harder to give a lot of attention to the newer, more difficult concepts talked about in lecture.

NO strengths. I hate this class. 
The workload of this course was completely INSANE and all for nothing because it only amounted for a minuscule percentage of your grade.  Additionally, the problem sets and practice problems felt useless  to the course and many times were all simply busy work with no purpose to retain knowledge. I appreciated that the material was broken down into sections as to not overwhelm but rather perfect each subject at hand; however, the way the exam was written, I felt did NOT coincide with the way material was taught for the majority of lectures. Lecture was more conceptual, so I focused on conceptual facts like what is an atom?, the exam was more qualitative like how many atoms are in X amount of moles of Y metal with weight of Z and dissolved in X at time Y and pressure Z. I felt this gap was meant to be closed in section but my section was not fruitful at all so I could not see that THAT was what I had to put my focus on, which I feel was completely an injustice to the students because of course those with good teaching fellows grasped this idea. Had I KNOWN the exams were set up in this manner I would've performed better in the course, and I did after i knew that's how this class "worked". And overall this class was meant and set up to address students with very little to no background in chemistry but there is no way someone could've gotten a perfect score without prior AP chemistry background, and I know this because several of my peers admitted they took this class as an "easier" option despite having taken AP chemistry and the higher level chemistry courses. The grading, the teaching style, the way the material was shown: THROW IT ALL AWAY and start over please. Also, there should be restrictions on the type of calculators allowed on tests because i think some very privileged people here have very nice calculators that can do more than just crunch numbers.

The course lacks an adequate amount of practice questions and the ones given are frustratingly not like the test questions. This results in people thinking they're prepared for tests when they really aren't.

I think a strength of the course was having so many opportunities to test yourself on the material and make sure you understood, from reflections to problem sets, so by the time the midterm was announced, you knew your own strengths and weaknesses. A weakness of this course was the disconnect between the lecture and the material. Often, I would walk out of lecture thinking I understood, but when I read the textbook and did the problem sets, I had no idea what was happening. I think bridging this gap would increase the level of comprehension in the course.
Yes, if you think youre interested in the natural sciences you should learn at least some chemistry.
I wouldn't say to take the course if a student is not interested in chemistry/bio/premed, but it is necessary for those subjects.
If you are pre-med, then yes. But otherwise, maybe not.

The course provides a strong chemical foundation for following courses.  I would recommend it only to people who have to take it as a prereq or who have time in their schedule to dedicate to the class because a lot of the material is self-learned and then glossed over in class.

Let's be real: most people are only taking this for pre-med or major requirements. I have no idea why you would want to take this otherwise. If you have a background from high school chemistry, it shouldn't be too difficult of a science credit.
Yes, it is a good introduction to chemistry. It does cover a lot of information, so I would only recommend it for those who are interested in chemistry, and not to students who need a QR credit.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This is a great course that does a good job of teaching basic chemistry. Grading is pretty fair and the workload is not overbearing. It is honestly a pretty good class.
If you're interested in chemistry or need the prerequisite, take the class. The workload is reasonable, and the textbook is helpful if you're confused.
Yes, they learn alot.
Yeah, this course was generally very fair with a lot of opportunity for help in whatever way the student was most comfortable.
Eh. You probably have to take it anyway. Otherwise, why bother?

The style of teaching in lecture is not the greatest but if you have a good TA it can make a world of difference. If not you may end up just having to teach a lot of the information to yourself. My TA was amazing, and the practice exams we were given before an exam was always similar to the real exam, something that I appreciated.
